text: In this lesson, we're going to take a look at texture and material optimizations. So let's get started. So textures should be treated based on priority in the shot. And that really goes for pretty much everything you put into Unreal. You have to think of it as a real-time tool and not an offline renderer tool for those that are working in film. For resolution to gain performance, and the highest is not always needed based on focus. Basically, your actor is the focus, and everything behind that actor, if it's directly behind him, needs to have a higher resolution. But if it's farther back, you can lower the resolution. I'll give you an example. If I had a mountain range and my texture for it was 8K, and it's way in the distance, I don't need 8K. I can lower that to an easy 4K or even 2K if I'm using Fog to hide some of the missing details. So that's actually really helpful to consider and think of things on that level. For large scenes that have lots of high resolution textures, say you have a terrain, maybe you're using virtual production, less of ICVFX, but more of a kind of maybe even a final pixel scenario, you can use virtual texturing so that only the highest resolution of the texture is loaded per where the camera and the focus areas are at.
